intro: Teucrium graecum, commonly known as Greek germander, is a perennial herb native to southern Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. Its small, tubular flowers are usually pink or purple, arranged in dense spikes, and bloom from late spring to early autumn. Teucrium graecum is often used in traditional medicine for its purported anti-inflammatory and antiseptic properties.
